channel.title: Egypt Revolution – Baraza
channel.description: Critical Collaboration on the Middle East, South Asia, and Africa

item.title: Modeling the Collective Hero: An Interview with Egyptian Playwright Ibrahim El-Husseiny
item.dc:creator: Hani Omer
item.description: Ibrahim El-Husseiny wrote the play “Comedy of Sorrows” only a few months after Egyptian president Hosni Mubarak’s resignation in February of 2011.  As such, it was one of the very first creative pieces produced in response to the Egyptian revolution.  Following a run of 60 performances in Egypt, a translation by Rebekah Maggor toured the States … Continue reading Modeling the Collective Hero: An Interview with Egyptian Playwright Ibrahim El-Husseiny →

item.title: “Sumeida’s Song: Giving Operatic Voice to Revolution in Egypt”
item.dc:creator: Hani Omer
item.description: “Egypt is heading towards civil war”, composer Mohammed Fairouz plainly states in discussion of his opera, Sumeida’s Song, which premiered at the Prototype Festival in SoHo. Civil war is perhaps too strong a word to describe the current state of affairs in Egypt, but few would argue with Fairouz that the … Continue reading “Sumeida’s Song: Giving Operatic Voice to Revolution in Egypt” →

item.title: “The Unknown”: A Coptic Spring?
item.dc:creator: Candace Lukasik
item.description: It is September 2009; I’m in Upper Egypt, on this particular night, at the monastery and commemoration site of three martyred youth of Coptic history in a suburb of Luxor. As I passed a pathway littered with garbage set ablaze, I am told to look down, walk fast, and stay close to the Coptic sisters … Continue reading “The Unknown”: A Coptic Spring? →
